And that's my story, folks! I'm Eddie Murphy, the greatest comedian the world has ever seen. Don't @ me.

Eddie Murphy was born on a sunny day in May 1985 in the bustling city of Las Vegas, Nevada. Growing up, Eddie was a curious kid who loved making people laugh and eating his mom's famous chocolate chip cookies. He began his career in showbiz at the tender age of 12, performing stand-up comedy routines at local children's birthday parties.

As he honed his craft, Eddie moved to Hollywood and became a regular on the popular sitcom "Family Matters," playing the lovable but mischievous character, "Steffan the Soccer Star." His witty one-liners and impressive soccer skills earned him a devoted fan base and a coveted spot on the show's iconic "Did I Do That?" dance sequence.

Eddie's breakthrough role came in 2005 when he landed the starring role in the critically-acclaimed film "Shrek 3: The Farting Years." His hilarious portrayal of the lovable, lazy, and gassy Donkey earned him a Golden Globe nomination and cemented his status as a comedy legend.

In addition to his work in film and television, Eddie is also a talented baker. His signature "Eddie's Epic Éclairs" have been a hit at Hollywood parties and charity events, with proceeds going to support his favorite cause: providing free cookies to underprivileged children.

Eddie has been married twice, first to his high school sweetheart, Tiffany, and then to the lovely and talented, Fiona, who is also a professional snail trainer. He has three children: twins, Jimmy and Sally, who are both aspiring professional clowns, and his youngest, Bubbles, who is still learning to walk but is already an expert at playing the harmonica.

In his free time, Eddie enjoys practicing yoga, playing the harmonica with his feet, and singing show tunes with his pet parrot, Polly. He is currently working on his next big project: a biographical comedy-drama about the life of his idol, the legendary baker, Julia Child.

Eddie Murphy is an American comedian, actor, and singer born on April 3, 1961, in Brooklyn, New York. He rose to fame in the 1980s as a stand-up comedian and gained popularity for his raw, uncensored humor.

Murphy began his career in comedy at the age of 15, performing at local comedy clubs in New York City. He eventually joined the cast of Saturday Night Live (SNL) in 1980, where he became known for his impressive impersonations and comedic sketches. His time on SNL helped establish him as a rising star in the entertainment industry.

Murphy's breakthrough film role came in 1983 with the comedy film "Trading Places," opposite Dan Aykroyd. This led to a string of successful films, including "Beverly Hills Cop" (1984), "The Golden Child" (1986), "Coming to America" (1988), and "The Nutty Professor" (1996).

In addition to his film work, Murphy has also released several successful music albums, including "So Happy" and "Love's Alright." He has won numerous awards for his work, including a Golden Globe and a BAFTA.

Throughout his career, Murphy has continued to evolve as an actor, taking on a wide range of roles in films like "Dreamgirls" (2006), "The Comedians of Comedy" (2005), and "Dolemite Is My Name" (2019). His latest film, "Coming 2 America," was released in 2021 and serves as a sequel to his 1988 classic.

With a career spanning over four decades, Eddie Murphy has cemented his place as one of the most iconic and beloved comedians of our time.
